texts.en:
Zainabu is 39 years old and married with  seven children. She runs a tailoring business in Jomvu, Mombasa. Her business has been in operation for the last ten years. 

This marks Zainabu's  third time borrowing to finance her business which is doing well. With this loan she plans to purchase more cloth materials, buttons, zips, scissors and thread for her business. 



The anticipated profits which will be generated from the business will be ploughed back for gradual expansion of the business and the repayment of the loan. Her dream is to become a successful business lady.

loans.use: to purchase more cloth materials, buttons, zips, scissors and thread.

loans.name: Elsia Rosario

texts.es:
Elsia Rosario tiene 27 años de edad es soltero tiene un hijo, vive con el hijo de un año en el Cantón Chillanes provincia de bolívar.

LA VRC MONTE DE LOS OLIVOS, se encuentra ubicada en la parroquia San José del Tambo a 60 minutos de la oficina conformada por 14 socios y socias. Esta Ventanilla se dedica a Labores Agrícolas de ciclo corto Siembra de maíz, naranja y cacao.

Elsia se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz, naranja y cacao las compras y las ventas las realiza en el Cantón Chillanes. Solicita el Crédito para comprar semillas, insumos agrícolas como urea, mata monte, fertilizantes, veneno para la maleza para mantener en buenas condiciones los cultivos.

El Crédito será de mucha ayuda porque podrá mejorar la calidad de vida. Los desafíos que se le presenta  muy frecuentes son: la competencia y las plagas. El sueño es que el hijo sea profesional.

En los tiempos libres le gusta  Escuchar música.
texts.en:
Elsia Rosario, 27, is single and has a son.  She lives with her one-year-old son in Chillanes Canton, Bolívar Province.

The “Monte de los Olivos” communal bank is located in San José del Tambo Parish sixty minutes from this office; it has 14 members, both men and women.  This communal bank’s members are short cycle corn, orange and cocoa bean farmers.

Elsia is a corn, orange and cocoa bean farmer. Her sales and her purchases take place in Chillanes Canton.  She’s asking for the loan to buy seeds and farming supplies like urea, Matamonte [herbicide], fertilizer and weed killer to maintain her crops in good condition.

The loan will be very helpful because it will improve her quality of life.  The challenges she faces are very frequent: competition and pests.  Her dream is that her son becomes a professional.  In her free time she enjoys listening to music.

loans.use: to buy seeds and farming supplies.

loans.name: Bidii Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Bidii Group in Western Kenya! Rose is the facilitator of the Bidii group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rose takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and because One Acre Fund has the best prices. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had an excellent maize yield harvesting five bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Rose was only able to harvest two bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Rose will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in raising livestock.

In 2012, the members of Bidii group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows nine people; six women and two men, plus the Field officer on the far left. The total number of members is nine but one is absent.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a 52-year-old married man with 15 children, living in Hioma, Uganda. The client deals in the buying and selling of maize and rice and has been doing this business for 15 years. The main challenge he faces is climatic change. His business goal is to expand his business and his personal goal is to educate his children. John needs a loan to buy maize and rice for resale.

loans.use: to purchase rice and maize for resale.

loans.name: Channy

texts.en:
Channy, 22, is married and has two children, of which her oldest daughter is still at school while the youngest son is too young to attend school. She lives in a flat area of the rural village located in the Ponhea Krek district where farming is common. She has been growing cassava for four years to make a living and in addition, her husband catches frogs for sale to gain additional income. With her current business, she earns $11 US per day to feed and support her family.

Channy has been with VisionFund for four years. She completely repaid her last loan with VisionFund. The loans from VisionFund helped her to afford a decent house and sufficient food. Now requesting for another loan, she will use this loan to buy cassava seedlings for her farm. She hopes to make more cassava and sell it for a good price so as to earn more income to make a living better and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy cassava seedlings for her farm.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en:
Pauline is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past 6 years, Pauline has operated a green grocery business, selling to local residents. She faces a major challenge of fluctuation in prices. She dreams of expanding her business to meet her customers' demands in the future.

With the 40,000 KES, she wants to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables, tomatoes, onions and potatoes

loans.name: Sran

texts.en: Sran, 49, is married, and resides with her husband and two children in Prey Veng Province, Cambodia. She is a tailor. Her husband sells toys in the market. Two of her children are garment workers. Sran is requesting a loan of USD 800 in order to purchase more toys for her husband to sell in order to generate more income to support the family. In the future, they would like to build a new house.

loans.use: to purchase more toys to sell.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman. She has four children aged from one to twelve years old. She describes herself as a generous woman. 
Elizabeth operates a retail stall where she sells cereals such as beans, maize, etc. She has been involved in this business for two years. Her business is located near a busy road and her main customers are residents of her home area. Elizabeth describes her biggest business challenge to be the high price of cereals. She will use her loan of 20,000 KES to buy bags of maize. Elizabeth's business goal is to own a big maize store and be a distributor to major towns within five years.

loans.use: to buy more bags of maize.

loans.name: Mohammed

texts.en:
Mohammed is 24 years old and divorced. he lives in Al Hashmi, Jordan.

Mohammed want to take a loan of 500 JD so he can purchase more goods for general trading to improve his social and commercial level by increase his income.

Mohammed is under 30 years old so his loan is a youth loan.

loans.use: to do general trading

loans.name: Cica Anne-Marie

texts.fr: Âgée de 47 ans, Cica Anne-Marie est mariée a un certains Edouard. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Cica Anne-Marie vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants, le diverses charges de la maison sont supportées par le couple. Cica Anne-Marie a arrêté l'école au niveau secondaire. Pour faire face aux besoins de la maison, Cica Anne-Marie vend  des tissus depuis neuf ans ; ce qui lui permet de contribuer à l'éducation et à l'entretien des enfants. Cica Anne-Marie s'approvisionne dans une marché du Bénin et à Lomé au TOGO. La clientèle de Cica Anne-Marie devient de plus en plus grandissante. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d'affaire et son revenu, Cica Anne-Marie sollicite une première fois l’appui financier de ALIDé.

loans.use: Acheter des tissus.

loans.name: Hồng's Group

texts.en:
Ms Hồng is 36 years old and she is a single parent with 1 child.
 
She has worked in agriculture raising pigs for 5 years.
Hồng lives in Trieu Son district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.
Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover the market need is low in this region. 
 
Hồng is a reputable person in the community. 
Although this is her  first loan in Thanh Hoa microfinance institution, all members agreed to vote her  to be the leader of solidarity group. 
The main hardship that Hồng faces is lack of capital.  She is requesting a loan to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in future.
With her business profit, Hồng hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to do well in school.

loans.use: to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Madam Elizabeth is the owner of the God is Good enterprise. She has been in business for sometime now but lacks the needed capital to grow it. She needs a loan of $800.00 from Kiva to help her do this. She is hopeful that this amount, when given, will move her business to a higher level. She will work tirelessly and pay back earnestly.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys sells chickens and eggs to nearby stores and to her neighbors. She started her business with the help of her mother who gave her $200 with which to start the business. Initially she only sold to her family members and friends but she gradually expanded her business in order to sell to stores and markets. She aspires to sell dairy products like cheese, milk and yogurt. She will use the loan to invest in these products and in chickens. She believes that the business will grow and her profits will increase with the introduction of these new products. She is sure that this increase in sales will allow her to better educate her four children, all of whom are in school.

Translated from Spanish by Susanna Heinz, Kiva Volunteer.

Gladys se dedica a la venta de pollos y huevos a tiendas y vecinos del sector. Ella empezo su negocio con la ayuda de su madre quien le facilito $ 200 dolares para que emprendiera el negocio. Al principio solo vendia para sus familiares y amigos y poco fue creciendo para poder vender a tiendas y mercados. Ella aspira vender productos lacteos como queso, leche y yogurt .Gladys usara el prestamo para invertir en productos lacteos y pollos .Ella tiene Fe que que con la introduccion de estos nuevos productos sus ganacias se incrementaran y su negocio crecera. Ella esta segura que sus ventas crecera y le podra dar una mejor educacion a sus hijos. Gladys tiene 4 hijos y todos estudian. Ella ayuda en el hogar con las ganancias de su negocio. Junto con el sueldo que gana su esposo, ellos pueden proveer a sus hijos con comida y educación. Tiene la seguridad que con la inversion que hara le permitira tener mejores ganancias y poder ayudar con una mejor educacion para sus hijos.

loans.use: Investment in dairy products like cheese and yogurt

loans.name: Zakir

texts.en: Zakir I. (his employee is pictured) sells footwear in the local bazaar in the town of Khachmaz on the North Eastern coast of Azerbaijan. Zakir is looking for funding so that he can purchase more footwear to sell at his stand.

loans.use: To purchase more footwear for his stall.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Mrs. Ky S., her husband, and their four children (two of them pictured here) live in Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  Mrs. Ky S. currently works as a grocer, earning $8/day, while her husband earns $6/day working as a motor-taxi driver.  They will use this loan to build rooms for renting, a business they hope to expand in the future.

loans.use: To build rooms for renting

loans.name: Pedro

texts.es:
Pedro is a 56 year old butcher, he is married to Suni Benitez who is 48 years old and she is a housewife, she helps him out at the business also. They have two sons who go to school in the city. Pedro’s mother in law lives with them because of her old age and health issues. Pedro starts his activities very early, at 5am he is already in his business which is located in the city market, at this time his wife milks the cows and feeds the cattle. He needs the loan to buy more cattle to work on the land; he does not plan to sacrifice his animals, because they are not apt for sacrifice.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Escalante, Kiva volunteer

Pedro tiene 56 años, de profesión carnicero, casado con Suni Benítez tiene 48 años, ama de casa, también le ayuda en el negocio. Tiene dos hijos, quienes estudian en el colegio de la cuidad, también vive con ellos la mamá de su esposa, quien debido a su edad avanzada se encuentra enferma. Pedro inicia sus actividades muy temprano, las 5 a.m. ya se encuentra en su puesto de trabaja que se ubica en el mercado de la ciudad, mientras en esa hora su esposa ordeñar su vacas y da alimentos a sus animales vacunos. Necesita el crédito para la compra de animales vacunos para faenarlos, ya que los animales que posee en su campo no pretenden sacrificarlos, ya que aun no son aptos para el sacrificio.

loans.use: Compra de animales vacunos

loans.name: Maimuna

texts.pt:
Maimuna is a single mother and lives in Mangundze with her only son, who is 14. She is the owner of a shop where she sells various essential products, clothing as well as bread, as she also has an oven. As the month of December approaches, which is the peak season for buying cashew nuts from farmers, she plans to use the current loan to purchase wrap skirts in bulk for trading in the context of the cashew nut campaign. Her son attends school. She entered the program just this year. This is the second loan she will take.

Translated from Portuguese by Leo Duran, Kiva Volunteer.

Maimuna e mae solteira e vive em Mangundze com o seu unico filho de 14 anos. Ela e proprietaria de uma loja onde vende produtos de primeira necessidade, roupa e pao uma vez que tambem tem um forno onde fabrica pao, e vende tambem roupa. Uma vez que se aproxima o mes de Dezembro altura previlegiada para a compra da castanha de caju aos camponeses, ela pretende usar o actual emprestimo para a compra de capulanas em grande quantidade para a troca no contexto da campanha da castanha de caju. O seu filho esta a estudar.Ela entrou para o programa ainda este ano. Este emprestimo e o segundo que ela esta a tomar.

loans.use: Maimuna runs a shop where she sells various products. She would like to use the money to buy wrap skits for trade in the cashew nut campaign.

loans.name: Fofoga

texts.en:
Running a fast-food stall for two years now has allowed this member to pay off all her loan and has improved her business. Fofoga A. is one of our very good clients who have shown so much effort in the programme, and she is still going strong. At 29, she is still very young to be in such a demanding business. She has two children and her husband is helping her a lot with the fast-food stall. It is the main source of income for their family.

Fofoga earns about $90 WST (US$ 36) daily and her business is up and running six days a week. She use her income on family expenses, for example, church, household bills, food, and also of course to pay back what she owes SPBD on her loans.

loans.use: To buy chicken, turkey, taro, curry, flour, soy sauce, and other ingredients for her fast-food stall

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokheng H., age 48, and his wife have been married since 1984. They have three children, one son and two daughters. One of their daughters is working in a garment factory and the other two children are studying in a local school. Sokheng and his family live along National Road Number Two, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. He has been in the house construction business since 1992. His wife stays at home and takes care of their children.

Sokheng is requesting a loan from MAXIMA for the first time, in the amount of $600. He will add this loan to his own money in order to finish building his house.

loans.use: To add to his own money to finish building his house

loans.name: Flora's Muafaka Group

texts.en:
Flora is 32 years old and is married with 2 children, ages 10 and 7. Flora owns a charcoal store which she started in 2006, and she works there every day from 6 am to 8 pm.

In the past, Flora has taken out 1successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who has a business dealing in food vending.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal.

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Mrs. Leng Y., 51, grows rice and a variety of vegetables and earns about $1 a day of profit. Her husband stays at home and helps his wife with the farming. They have 5 children, one of who is married and lives away from home. Three others are employed by a garment factory and each earn a salary of $70 a month. The youngest child is a student. To reduce expenses, this couple requests a loan from Kiva to purchase a motorbike for their children to commute to work. This will allow the family save for the future. (Picture: husband and wife,  the children behind are the neighbors kids).

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for their children to commute to work.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn A. is twenty-nine years old, married, and the mother of two children. She has been operating a beauty salon for the past ten years. An enterprising person, Evelyn has eight apprentices who are currently learning the hair business from her.

She wants to use her loan to buy more hair products, such as conditioner, perm gel, and lotions, to sustain her operation. She hopes to increase her savings to pay for her children’s education.

Evelyn is a member of the group called “Mpaebo Tiefo” (meaning Prayer Listening God). Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other in repaying the loan.

In the photo, Evelyn is seated in front of her apprentices.

loans.use: To buy more hair cream and other products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Corina Del Socorro

texts.es:
In the municipality of Ciudad Sandino in Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, Ms. Corina Narvaez dedicates great effort to the business of sewing. She has her own sewing machines, with which she embroiders all types of clothes, from shirts to dresses for all ages. In spite of her difficult economic situation that has been an obstacle for a long time, today she has improved the living conditions of her two small children, who really depend on her. She needs financial support to purchase tools for work such as fabrics, threads, needles, etc.and for this sensible reason she has come to CEPRODEL to obtain the credit that will give her the opportunity to obtain materials to continue with the business in her home.

Translated from Spanish by Helen Smith, Kiva volunteer.

En el municipio de Ciudad Sandino de Managua capital de Nicaragua, la señora Corina N. se dedica con muchísimo esfuerzo al negocio de costurera teniendo sus propias maquinas de coser con la que elabora todo tipo de ropa desde camisas hasta vestidos para todas las edades. A pesar de su difícil situación económica que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado hoy en día ha mejorado la condición de vida de sus dos pequeños hijos que tanto necesitan de ella.

La necesidad atravesada por la señora Carina es que está necesitando el apoyo financiero para la compra de las herramientas de trabajo como telas, hijos, agujas, etc. por esta sencilla razón ha acudido a CEPRODEL para obtener el crédito que le de la oportunidad de obtener los materiales para continuar con el negocio en su localidad de habitación.

loans.use: Purchase of sewing materials

loans.name: Neydi

texts.es:
In the city of Managua, in the market of Israel Lewites, Mrs. Neydi Sanchez makes a living in her business selling fruits and vegetables.

She started her business 8 years ago by selling few products. Today, thanks to her efforts and the support provided by Ceprodel, she has increased her inventory and is able to offer greater quantities of fruits and vegetables to her clientèle.

The need which she is currently undergoing is the urgency to get funds for the purchase of products. This is why she is coming to Ceprodel to obtain the credit and in this way forge ahead with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


En la ciudad de Managua, en el Mercado Israel Lewites la señora Neydi Sanchez se dedica a su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras las cuales las comercializa en su tramo en dicho mercado.

Su negocio lo inició desde hace 8 años vendiendo pocos productos y hoy en día gracias al aporte brindado por Ceprodel ha incrementado su inventario ofreciendo mayores cantidades de frutas y verduras para sus clientes.

La necesidad que hoy en día ella atraviesa es la urgencia de adquirir el recurso económico para la compra de sus productos. Por esto es que ella acude a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito y de esta manera salir adelante junto con su familia.

loans.use: Compra de las frutas y verduras / Buying fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Alma Nidia

texts.es:
Alma Nidia works selling tortillas she makes herself. She also sells firewood and sells prepared meals to construction workers, although tortilla sales are the most important part of her business.

Alma Nidia has been in this business for 6 years; along the way she struggled due to the lack of financing available to the food sector. She has now been working with AFODENIC for several years, and has been able to invest more in her business thanks to the loans she's received.

She began the business selling only tortillas and has now been able to diversify her business a little more, although she still needs to expand her client base in order to improve her profitability. She will use this loan to buy corn and firewood, basic raw materials for the production of tortillas and prepared meals.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva Volunteer.

Alma Nidia se dedica a la venta de tortillas que ella misma produce. La venta de tortillas es su actividad más fuerte, aunque también vende leña y hace comida de venta para trabajadores de la construcción.

Tiene 6 años en el negocio y se le ha hecho difícil debido a la falta de financiamiento para este secto, hace algunos años trabaja con AFODENIC y ha podido invertir más a su negocio.

Empezó vendiendo tortillas y ya pudo diversificar su oferta un poco más, aunque necesita mayor captación de clientes para así ser más rentable. El préstamo lo usará en compras de maíz y leña, granos básicos para elaboración de tortillas y comidas

loans.use: Purchase corn and firewood

loans.name: Maria Neria

texts.es:
María Neria and her family moved to Reynosa dreaming of a better future, as in their own region employment opportunities were scarce. Upon arriving in Reynosa, her husband started looking for a job and found one. As time went on, they began to save so they would have some money available for any situation that arose.

Later her husband was laid off and with their savings, she started her own food business so that they could keep up with their household expenses. Little by little she increased her supply and variety of food and up to now things have gone well.

She is currently requesting a loan for US $500, which will be repaid in 6 month, to buy more supplies, and she hopes that with Kiva´s support she will receive the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglsi, Kiva volunteer.

María Neria junto con su familia emigró a Reynosa con el sueño de tener un mejor futuro, ya que en su tierra natal las fuentes de ingresos eran muy escasas, al llegar aquí su esposo empezó a buscar empleo, el cual lo consiguió, al paso del tiempo, empezaron a ahorrar para tener dinero disponible para cualquier situación. Posteriormente a su esposo lo desocuparon del empleo, entonces con los ahorros que tenían ella decidió poner su propio negocio de comidas, para poder salir adelante con los gastos económicos. Poco a poco le fue surtiendo y teniendo variedad de comida, hasta hoy en día le ha ido muy bien.

Actualmente esta solicitando un crédito por US $500 a 6 meses, para la compra de mercancía, tiene todas las esperanzas que con el apoyo de Kiva lo obtendrá.

loans.use: Purchase supplies.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is 39 years old and lives in the tropical Santa Cruz region of eastern Bolivia. She lives in her 34-year-old brother's house along with her family and her three-year-old son. She and her brother are taking out this loan together

Flora sells groceries out of her home with the help of her mother. She also works at the ALG poultry farm giving vaccinations to the animals. Her brother works on the "Inacruz" poultry farm, where he works as a mechanic and welder. He also owns a stand on 25th of May St. (the main street in the area where they live) where he sells drinks. Both Flora and her brother have many years of experience in their respective activities. Though there is some competition both in grocery sales and drink sales, Flora and her brother never lack customers, since they both have experience running high-quality operations. Each has a steady source of income, as well, so their earnings are fairly stable.

Flora plans to use her loan to buy more groceries. This is her third loan with AgroCapital, and she has been an excellent client in the past. She does not have any outstanding debts with any other financial institutions.

loans.use: Buy bulk groceries to sell

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 36-year-old Miriam from Dar es Salaam. She is married with two children between the ages of three and 14 years. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents do not take care of them. Miriam has been running a pharmacy since 2005. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for nine hours per day, five days per week and is assisted by one employee. Miriam currently earns about 100 USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 250 USD in order to purchase additional medicine for her business. In the future, she plans to increase her business through new product offerings. Miriam thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit through micro-leasing in Tanzania. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women and uses the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus they are deemed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro-leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To replenish her inventory of medicines

loans.name: Sadith Belmira

texts.es:
La señora Sadith pertenece al Banco Comunal “Corazón D. Jesús”, ubicado en el Jr. Virgen del Pilar Mz. H Lt. 2, distrito D. Yarinacocha, provincia D. Coronel Portillo, departamento D. Ucayali. Tiene 47 años D. edad, es madre D. 5 hijos, 4 mayores D. edad y uno que aún depenD. D. ella, es casada y su esposo es independiente. Con el primer préstamo que recibió D. Manuela Ramos D. S/. 300 deciD. invertir en la venta D. frutas y comida. Tiene 2 años trabajando con el banco comunal.

En la actualidad trabaja en el programa D. WAWA WASI. Cuenta con una motokar como herramienta D. trabajo para mejorar su estabilidad económica.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 1,500, el cual será pagado en 4 meses, comprará 2 llantas, 4 focos, también arreglará el motor y tapizará los asientos. 

Sadith se siente agradecida con Manuela Ramos porque ha logrado comprar una movilidad propia para el beneficio D. su menor hija.
texts.en:
Sadith belongs to the community bank "Corazon D. Jesus" located at Jr. Virgen del Pilar Mz. H. Lt. 2, in the district of Yarinacocha in the province of Coronel Portillo in Ucayali. She is 47 years old and she is the mother of 5 children, 4 of whom are of age and one that still depends no her. She is married and her husband works in dependently. With the first loan received from Manuela Ramos, amounting to S/.300, she decided to invest in the sale of fruit and prepared food. She has been with the community bank for the past 2 years.

Currently she is working within the program of WAWA WASI. She has a moto-car as a work tool and she uses it to improve her financial stability.

Sadith feels grateful for Manuela Ramos because she has been able to purchase her own transportation, and it is for the benefit of her young daughter.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase 2 tires, 4 head lights, and to repair the motor and refinish the seats.

loans.name: Sambou

texts.en: Mrs. Sambou K. is a villager in Ou Sngoeun village in Takeo Province. She and her husband, Mr. Kann Samoeurn, are farmers who own a piece of land where they cultivate rice. T In order to improve their living conditions, Mrs. Sambou K. is requesting a loan to buy four piglets and pig food to start a pig-breeding business. She is 47 years old and the mother of eight children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and pig food to start a pig-breeding business

loans.name: Nurillojon

texts.en:
Nurillojon is originally from Isfara, Tajikistan. For 17 years he has been processing and selling dried apricots. Nurillojon is married with two children. Family effort has been the key to his business's growth since everyone collaborates and now, he has a steady customer base due to the quality of his products. At the high season, he even sends some of his products to Russia where dried apricots are very expensive. Currently, he is seeking a loan of 4000 Somoni (US$ 1175) to buy tables so he can buy more dried apricots in order to fill the high demand from his customers. He promises to repay this loan in 11 months. Be a part of this family's achievements! They sincerely thank you for your support.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and with it’s famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets as: Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy dried apricots to expand his business

loans.name: Primitiva

texts.es: Primitiva acaba de cumplir 37 años, hace exactamente 14 años viene conviviendo con su pareja, con el que tiene 3 hijos y viven en su casa propia. Al iniciar su matrimonio, tenía la idea de tener una bodega, pero su esposo es agricultor, entonces tuvo que seguir con la misma labor para el sustento de su familia, luego su esposo tuvo la oportunidad de trabajar en el tendido de redes eléctricas en otra ciudad y Primitiva se quedó a cargo de sus chacras. Pese a que no le agradan las labores agrícolas se dedica con mucha entrega a cuidar y cultivar los terrenos sembrados por su esposo, asimismo quiere sembrar las semillas de papa que guardó su esposo, y lo hará con el apoyo de peones. Su esposo siempre tuvo fe y cree que es muy rentable la siembra de papa semilla, por ello Primitiva quiere continuar con la próxima siembra, después de cosechar este producto lo seleccionan de acuerdo al tamaño para la venta como semilla, ya que no es para consumo. Primitiva está muy contenta al saber que este banco comunal le brinda su apoyo, y por las facilidades de pago que tiene en MPF, y está comprometida a pagar las cuotas fijadas en las fechas exactas, para ganarse la confianza del grupo, ya que es su primer préstamo. El dinero que está solicitando es para comprar abono y concretizar la siembra de la papa semilla que tiene guardada.
texts.en:
Primitiva just turned 37. When she came to MFP exactly 14 years ago, she was living with her husband and their three children in her own home. When Primitiva was first married she had the idea of owning a small store, but her husband is a farmer and had to keep working the fields to support the family. Later he found a job hanging electrical wires in another city and Primitiva was left to care for the fields. She cultivated the crops planted by her husband and with the help of laborers she also planted potato seeds that her husband had stored. Primitiva's husband has always been a man of faith and she believes that planting potatoes is profitable. Even though her current crop won't be large enough to sell for food, Primitiva would like to sell it for seed and continue to plant potatoes for the next harvest. Primitiva is happy to know that this community bank supports her, and because of the ease of paying with MPF she is prepared to repay her loan on the exact dates specified. She'll do this to earn the confidence of the group, as this is her first loan. The money will go to buy fertilizer and to finish planting the potato seeds that she has saved.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fertilizer

loans.name: Eveline

texts.es: Eveline tiene 25 años de edad, es madre soltera, tiene una hija, y actualmente realiza un negocio de producción de comidas en un local alquilado. Cuando ella vivía con su padres, solo se dedicaba a estudiar, pero cuando tuvo a su hijo, del cual tuvo que hacerse cargo ella sola; debido a las necesidades que requería el pequeño; decidió incursionar en el negocio de vender comida, entonces alquiló un local con buena ubicación por donde circulara mucha gente y pasaran los todos los carros y buses interprovinciales, es así que los chóferes se convirtieron en sus principales clientes, siendo uno de los restaurantes más concurridos de la zona, permitiéndole así cubrir los gastos de alquiler del local donde paga 150 soles y para la manutención de su pequeño. A Eveline le gusta su trabajo, por ello inicia sus actividades a las 5 de la mañana y cierra a las 9 de la noche, cuando los buses hayan terminado de pasar. En estas fechas la venta no es tan buena, vendiendo de 18 a 25 platos, pero en tiempos de cosecha de café las ventas al día, son de 35 a 40 platos, ganancias le permiten darle a su hijo algunas comodidades. Eveline en todo este tiempo ha demostrado ser una cliente puntual en sus pagos a MFP, ella está en su quinto préstamo, aunque no puede asistir con mucha frecuencia a las reuniones de su banco comunal porque no hay quien la remplace en su negocio. El dinero que solicita es para la compra de víveres para que pueda preparar los menús diarios en su restaurante, y de ese modo irse preparando para las fechas de la cosecha del café que ya se aproximan, desde aquí agradece a las personas que hacen posible que ella pueda seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
Eveline is 25 years old and the single mother of one daughter. She currently runs a business making prepared foods in a rented space. When she lived with her parents, she only dedicated herself to her studies. However, once she had a child, she started her business from the rented locale in order to meet her financial needs. She rented a location that is well-situated, through which a great number of people circulate as well as the buses and cars that travel between provinces. In this way, the drivers of these vehicles became some of her best customers, and her restaurant is one of the most frequented in the area. This has allowed her to pay the rent of 150 soles for her location, and also to support her daughter. Eveline enjoys her work, which is why she starts as early as 5 am and closes at 9 pm when the buses stop running. These days, business is not great and she sells 18 to 25 dishes. However, during the coffee harvest season she sells upwards of 35 to 40 plates a day, allowing her to provide some comforts for her daughter. Eveline has shown at all times to be punctual with her payments to MFP, and she is in her fifth loan. She isn’t able to attend the reunions of her cooperative bank very often, because there is no one to fill in at the business for her. The funds she requests are for the purchase of provisions so she can prepare her daily menus and, in this way, begin to prepare for the coffee harvest season which is approaching. From here, she thanks the people who make it possible for her to continue to work.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase provisions for her restaurant.

loans.name: Soonalote

texts.en: Soonalote T., 25, is married and has one child. This is her first year in the farming business. She sells to the villagers and public two days per week. She has never had a loan with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 210 Tala (~$87 USD). SPBD loans are Soonalote’s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy chemicals and equipment for her business

loans.name: Artene

texts.en:
Artene R. has an individual enterprise in Bratulei village, Nisporeni district. Artene's business is favorably located in the middle of the town, other competitors are not. He has been working for 4 months. Artene has 287 rooms with a surface of 2 square meters to conduct business. At the moment, he opened a hall of ceremonies and he can rent the hall for weddings. Since Artene has the space, he wants to open a food store and bar to expand his business. During the 4 months of activity Artene noticed that the wedding guests going to the stores nearby to serve coffee, tea, beer, and he got the idea of opening a shop-bar. 

Arten is photographed here before the repair of shop.

To open the store Artene needs to buy refrigeration display cabinets and cold foods. The goods will be purchased centrally from wholesale bases in Ungheni town and Nisporeni, from producers in the amount of 25-30000 lei. Monthly performance will be 35-42000 lei. 

Artene wants to thank Microinvest for the services and of course KIVA lenders.

loans.use: buying refrigeration display cabinets and cold foods

loans.name: Germaine

texts.fr: Madame germaine A. est une femme qui habite le quartier d'attiégou qui est un quartier périphérique de la ville de lomé. elle exerce depuis 2004 le commerce de charbons de bois qui est très utilisé pour préparer de la nourriture au Togo. le stock dont elle dispose actuellement est insuffisant pour satisfaire sa clientèle.Pour pouvoir se réapprovisionner elle sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 20 sacs de charbons de bois. elle est mariée à un monsieur qui est blanchisseur.ils ont 03 enfants.
texts.en:
Mrs. Germaine A. lives in the Attiégou district, an outlying neighborhood of the city of Lomé. Since 2004, she has been selling charcoal, which is much used for cooking in Togo. Her present stock is insufficient to satisfy the needs of her customers. For that reason, she is asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 20 sacks of charcoal. She is married to a gentleman who makes bleach. They have 3 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Fast Moving Group

texts.en:
These are Adama K., Isatu T., and Suad B.. They named their group Fast Moving. They are local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, twenty miles from Freetown, Sierra Leone’s capital city. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are getting from SMT/Kiva. They are requesting a loan of Le 500,000 each. This loan will create meaningful impacts in the lives of these people. They will be able to use the proceeds to pay their children’s school fees. They will also able to feed and clothe themselves and their children with the income generated from the loans.

Adama K. (middle) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-eight years of age and was born in Kambia, northern Sierra Leone. She is married to a motorcycle driver and they have three children. Their first child is no longer attending school and the other two are in Junior Secondary Schools. Adama owns a grocery store. She has been a businesswoman since childhood days.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Ana Margarita

texts.es: La Señora Ana Margarita L. Martínez tiene la edad de 27 años, su estado civil es soltera. Doña Ana tiene 1 hijo y estudia. La actividad económica es la venta de comida. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. Doña Ana tiene poco de tener este negocio, pero es importante resaltar que nació con el objetivo de apoyar los gastos de su familia ella es una mujer muy luchadora, y siempre le ha gustado trabajar de una manera humilde. Los propósitos de Ana son de aumentar su inventario y así tener las reservas necesarias de los productos que son mas solicitados. El financiamiento es solicitado para capital de trabajo en la compra de arroz, frijoles, azúcar, frutas. El deseo de Doña Ana es obtener la mejor calidad de comida entre sus clientes, y establecer un restaurante en donde genere ganancias para su familia.
texts.en:
Señora Ana Margarita L. Martínez is 27 and single. Doña Ana has one son and goes to school. She makes a living by selling food. She has done this for more than 5 years. She hasn't had this business very long, but it's important to point out that she created it with the objective of supporting her family. She is a very hard-working woman, and she has always liked to work in a humble manner. Ana's goals are to increase her inventory so she can have the necessary reserves of her most requested products. The financing requested will go towards working capital so she can buy rice, beans, sugar, and fruits. Doña Ana's dream is to make the best quality food for her customers and to establish a restaurant that will generate profits for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Abdul Jalil Group

texts.en:
This is the Abdul Jalil group. Led by Abdul Jalil, the group is made up of five members, each of whom would like to obtain a loan to improve their businesses:

- Abdul Jalil wants to take out a loan for his flower shop. - Shellah would like to request a loan for her tailoring business. - Shakaba would like a loan to apply toward her her bead-working. - Anufa hopes to receive a loan for her husband, who sells cigarettes from his cart. - M. Osian wishes to obtain a loan for his cloth-selling shop.

Togther, they hope to expand their businesses with this loan of 70,000 Afghani. They are happy to have the opportunity to apply for a loan that helps support entrepreneurs in this way.

loans.use: For expanding their businesses

loans.name: Jomie

texts.en:
Aside from his farming business, Jomie D. of Norala, South Cotabato manages a piggery with his wife.

Jomie is 33 and the father of two. As a couple, their main goal is to send their children to school and see them obtain their degrees. This motivates Jomie to strive harder as a responsible breadwinner.

Jomie’s membership in the Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) paves his way to be closer to his dreams. He is applying for a Php 10,000 loan from CEVI. This sum will be used to purchase some farming necessities.

Jomie is blessed with their monthly meetings in CEVI because the learning he gets he also shares with his family. This makes him a better husband and father in the family.

loans.use: To buy farm necessities

loans.name: Yumjirdulam

texts.en:
Yumjirdulam A. is 38 years old and lives with her husband and two teenage children in Ovorhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two children are both students in local high schools.

She has a small retail business in butchery. She rents a small stall at the local food market and sells cut meat. She purchases livestock from the wholesale market in the town and slaughters them at home. She cuts the carcasses in small pieces and retails them at the local market. She also sells the skins and other internal organs and parts at the market as well. She has been in the meat retail business for over eight years and has gained significant experience. Her husband owns a small truck and he sometimes travels to herder families nearby and purchases livestock for discounted prices. She says that she would like to expand her business and make it a more profitable large-scale family business. She is requesting a loan to purchase more livestock for her meat business.

loans.use: To purchase whole animals at wholesale prices.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes B. sells bananas and bowls at Beposo near Shama. Agnes has received junior high school education. She is a single parent and has two children.

Agnes has been selling bananas and bowls since 2007. She is responsible for providing food for her family. Her loan will be used to expand her business by buying more and a variety of fruits and some other cooking utensils. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to pay her children’s school fees.

loans.use: buying more and a variety of fruits and some other cooking utensils for resale

loans.name: Miriam

texts.es:
La señora Miriam R. S. por más de 15 años se ha dedicado a su negocio de venta de frutas y verduras en el departamento de León donde a diario vende los productos perecederos como frutas y verduras.

La razón por la que ha solicitado el crédito es para la compra de los perecederos como lo son tomates, cebollas, chiltomas, pitahayas, bananos, mamones, entre otros. Ella espera en que el crédito le será otorgado y así suplirá su pequeña venta de frutas y verduras.
texts.en:
Sra. Miriam R. S. has been selling fruits and vegetables in the District of León for over 15 years. Her perishable products are sold every day.

She has requested a loan so that she buy perishable items such as tomatoes, onions, peppers, pitahaya (cactus fruit), bananas, mamoncillos, and other items. She hopes that her loan will be approved so that she can purchase a small supply of fruits and vegetables to sell.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits & vegetables

loans.name: Basilia

texts.en: Basilia sells spare motor parts. She is 35 years old and married with 3 children. Basilia hopes for the loan amount of N140,000 to purchase more spare parts to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more spare motor parts to sell

loans.name: Yeny

texts.es:
La socia se llama Yeny, ella pertenece al banco del grupo esperanza, es socia activa y junto a su pareja, trabajan juntos.

La socia tiene 30 años  de edad, ella es conviviente y  tiene 1 pequeño hijo, nuestra socia alterna sus diferentes actividades del hogar con la venta de ropa, ella junto a su pareja compran ropa al por mayor y la venden, nuestra socia solicita el préstamo para poder adquirir mayor mercadería y así seguir vendiendo sus diferentes prendas.

La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de su deuda en el plazo establecido.

loans.use: Capital de trabajo.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: purchasing fertilizer and paying for plowing

loans.name: Lily

texts.en:
Lily G. is currently in the business of selling cooking oil and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and tomatoes to sell. Lily is 23 years old and is married to a chief. She has three children who do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her family.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase onions and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila B. is from the village of Southern Pob., Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Sheila is single and has two children. To make a living, Sheila owns and operates a specialized "sari-sari" retail store, selling retail products like such as soap, salt, sugar, noodles and other daily use products. Sheila has been in business for over five years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Sheila joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sheila has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. Sheila is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Sheila from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Caleb

texts.en:
Caleb O. is a married man, 29 years old. His wife Susan Otieno is a business lady and they are blessed with one child. 

Caleb operates a welding business that has been in operation for two years in Kiembeni. He mainly serves the residents of Kiembeni and surrounding hotels by making metal doors and windows for them.

Caleb was introduced to KADET by a client and this marks his first loan from KADET. He plans to purchase metal bars that he will use in his welding station.

In the future, he hopes to own fabrication and metal works machines to help him stabilize his business.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase metal bars.

loans.name: Martha Mayra

texts.es:
La señora Martha Mayra C. M., tiene 51 años de edad, vive en el Barrio “Sabana Grande” conocido por ser un barrio con una inseguridad bien alta, es madre soltera tiene una hija de 29 años mayor de edad que vive con ella y comparten los gastos de su hogar. La señora C. se dedica desde hace 26 años a la elaboración de “Cosa de Horno” un dulce típico de nuestro país, solicitó un préstamo para invertirlo en su negocio  en la compra de maíz, queso y leña para la elaboración de esta repostería.
 
Los Planes de vida, que la señora anhela a un futuro, son el poder mejorar  el horno donde realiza su repostería debido a que es su  fuente de ingresos y que tiene 100 años de existencia, pero para este fin necesitara de una mayor inyección de capital, que espera percibir con esta inversión que efectuará.
texts.en:
Mrs. Martha Mayra C. M. is 51 years old, and she lives in the “Sabana Grande” neighborhood, one known for the lack of safety its residents experience. Martha is a single mother of a 29-year-old daughter, who lives with her and shares the household expenses. For the past 26 years, Martha has been baking “Cosa de Horno” (oven thing), a traditional Nicaraguan sweet dish. She is requesting the loan buy corn, cheese, and firewood to bake these sweets. Martha's plan for the future includes making improvements to the oven in which she bakes her sweets since the oven is practically the source of her income and is already 100 years old. For this, she will need more capital, which she expects to obtain from the earnings that will result from the investment she will make with this loan's proceeds.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying raw materials to bake traditional sweets.

loans.name: Elizabeth Maria

texts.es:
Elizabeth María A., es la segunda de una familia conformada por cuatro hermanos, es casada  y tiene una hija de 13 años en Noveno grado de secundaría, vive en Galapa pueblo que la vio nacer y uno de los más antiguos del Departamentos del Atlántico, con una gran riqueza cultural, donde las máscaras en madera y papel mache, las artesanías de bejuco, la confección, pintura en tela  y la danza son actividades que recogen la tradición de sus habitantes y enriquecen una de las fiestas mas importantes de Colombia, como lo es el Carnaval de Barranquilla, ciudad ubicada a 15 minutos de Galapa..  
  
Elizabeth María, cursó hasta Segundo año de primaria y aprendió a comunicarse con sus familiares y particulares por el lenguaje de señas de una forma empírica, debido a que no realizó estudios pertinentes como persona en condición de discapacidad auditiva. Pero su familia, eje principal de su crecimiento personal, la ayudó a identificar sus potencialidades realizando cursos técnicos en pintura, lo que le permitió iniciar tres años después, un pequeño negocio de manualidades, decoración y pinturas en tela, con el que ha desarrollado su autoconfianza y autosuficiencia. Así, con su inmenso deseo de superación y ese especial estimulo afectivo, aprendió a coser en una maquina familiar y hoy elabora prendas de vestir a los que le aplica las técnicas aprendidas como valor agregado y son productos alternos que han ampliado su mercado y que ha logrado con el apoyo financiero de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo entidad con la que esta vinculada hace tres (3) años

En la actualidad espera recibir un préstamo por valor de $1.500.000 que reembolsará en un plazo de 18 meses, 45% del cual invertirá en pañolenci, lentejuelas, mostacillas y variedad de aplicaciones, con un brillo exclusivo para  adornar las viviendas y a las familias en la época navideña, con manteles, cojines, sabanas, fundas, edredones, toallas, almohadas, baja ollas, tapetes, cortinas y diversos cuadros que embellecen los hogares de quienes lo han solicitado; el 55% restante, lo invertirá en telas para elaborar vestidos sobre pedidos, que sus clientes usaran en estas fiestas. Elizabeth proyecta  en esta época de alta comercialización aumentar  sus ventas y con la  utilidad esperada ahorrará para pagar el crédito, los gastos  del colegio de su hija del año 2010 y reinvertirá de acuerdo con la época que se avecina en los meses de Enero y febrero, relacionada con el ingreso de los estudiantes al colegio y las fiestas del Carnaval de Barranquilla simultáneamente.

Elizabeth María, es una excelente miembro de familia y muy responsable en el cumplimiento de sus obligaciones financieras, durante 3 años que lleva accediendo a tres créditos de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo los ha rembolsado oportunamente, porque los direcciona  al aumento de su capital de trabajo para poder crecer y sostenerse. Ella sueña a mediano plazo con tener un local y  una  nueva maquina  de coser que permita dar un mejor acabado a las prendas y fortalecer su mercado en otras localidades cercanas, pero reconoce que debe esperar hacer unos esfuerzos mayores de incursión comercial  para poder cumplir sus metas.
texts.en:
Elizabeth María A. is the second of four siblings. She is married and has a 13-year-old daughter who is in 9th grade. She lives in Galapa, her home town, and one of the oldest in Atlántico department. It is rich in cultural history, especially the wood and papier mache masks, woven reed crafts, sewing, painting on fabric, and dance. These activities gather the traditions of its inhabitants and enrich Colombia’s most famous festivals like the Carnival in Barranquilla, a city that is located 15 minutes away from Galapa. Elizabeth María finished second grade and taught herself in an empirical way how to communicate with her family and others using signs because, being hearing impaired, she never had the proper training in these skills. But her family, who are her guiding posts with respect to her personal development, helped her to realize her potential by providing her with technical painting courses. This allowed her, three years later, to be able to set up a small crafts business which consists of decoration and painting of fabrics. With this, her self-esteem and her self-sufficiency grew. Thus, with her immense desire to better herself and the loving support of her family, she learned how to sew on a family sewing machine and today she makes articles of clothing on which she applies the learned skills as value added. These are alternative products that have expanded her market and that have been made possible thanks to financial support from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, with whom she has been associated for the last 3 years. Currently, she hopes to receive a loan for $1.500.000 that will be repaid in 18 month. 45% of it will be used to buy felt appliqués, sequins, beads, and a variety of other appliqués specially selected to decorate homes and families during the Christmas season with tablecloths, cushions, sheets, comforters, towels, pillows, trivets, throw rugs, curtains, and pictures that beautify the homes of those that request them. 55% will be used to buy fabric to make dresses on order that her customers will wear during these festivities. Elizabeth projects that this high sales season will increase her profits from which she will save enough to repay the loan, pay for her daughter’s 2010 school expenses and still have some to reinvest for the January and February seasons that are approaching, which are related to back-to-school and Carnival in Barranquilla. Elizabeth María is an excellent family member and very responsible with respect to her financial obligations. She has had 3 loans in the three years that she has been getting loans from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo; she has always repaid them in a timely fashion because she invests them in her business to grow and sustain herself. She hopes in the not too distant future to have a workshop and a new sewing machine that will permit her to make still better finishings on her clothing and to strengthen her market in nearby locations but she knows that she might have to make greater efforts to make commercial inroads if she is to reach her goals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric, thread, pañolenci (felt appliqués), sequins, beads, and a variety of other appliqués for handicrafts and seasonal costumes.

loans.name: Suon

texts.en: Suon K. is 43 years of age and is currently a resident of Siem Reap province, located about over 300 kilometers from Phnom Penh. To earn a living, she and her husband always wake up in the late morning to go to the middle of the river by boat with some tools and they fish. They hurry up and bring their fish to sell at retail in the market when they finish fishing. This couple is able to earn $5 per day, which they use to cover their family’s daily living expenses. Recently a machine on their fishing boat broke down while they were catching fish. Suon K. is applying for a loan to replace the broken machine. Suon K. has given birth to four young children who are going to school or to work.

loans.use: To replace broken equipment

loans.name: Josué Ovidio

texts.es: Josué Ovidio N. G. de 50 años de edad, reside en el departamento de Usulután y vive en casa propia junto a su esposa, quien le ayuda en el negocio y tres hijos que se dedican a estudiar. Él posee una venta de carne de res, la cual está ubicada frente a la parroquia de Ozatlán, en el departamento de Usulután, este lugar es muy concurrido y siempre cuenta con una gran afluencia de personas. Josué posee 23 años de dedicarse a este negocio, es por ello que es muy reconocido en el lugar, y cuenta con la confianza de sus clientes quienes aseguran que él es una persona muy trabajadora quien ha salido adelante gracias su esfuerzo y el de su esposa. Josué solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda contar con el dinero necesario para comprar mayor cantidad de carne, y así obtenerla a menor precio, también desea poder invertir en especias para dar sabor a las comidas. Josué desea mucho poder invertir más en el negocio de manera que pueda renovarlo después de tantos años y así poder obtener mejores ganancias, ofreciendo mayor cantidad de carne a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Josué Ovidio N. G. is 50 years old and lives in the department of Usulután. He lives in his own house together with his wife, who helps him in the business, and his three children who are studying. He owns a beef shop that is located in front of the parish of Ozatlán, in the department of Usulután. This place is busy and he can always count on a great crowd of people. Josué has been in this business for 23 years, and it’s for this reason that he is very well-known in the area. He counts on the confidence of his customers who assure that he very hard-working and has succeeded thanks to his own efforts and his wife’s efforts. Josué is asking for a loan through which he can have the money to buy a larger quantity of meat and therefore get a lower price. He also hopes to invest in spices to give flavor to the food. Josué would really like to invest more in the business so that he can renovate it after so many years and therefore be able to obtain a better income, offering a larger quantity of meat to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Kelley Maynard, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of meat and spices

loans.name: Apoowegi Akidi Christine Group

texts.en: A. Christine is a business woman of thirty-two years, married with three children in schooling. She also has 7 other dependents, 2 of which are still in schooling. She has sold smoked fish for the past 5 years. She is using the loan to purchase fish and sell to her customers. The loan is adding capital into her business improving stock. She is a hardworking business woman whose dreams are to educate her children and build a better house.

loans.use: To purchase fish and sell to her customers.

loans.name: Lila

texts.en:
Mrs. Lila D. is a grocery shopkeeper in the village of Chapagaun, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband and one son. Her husband is a driver and her son studies in primary school.

Mrs. D. opened her grocery store five years ago to improve the economic condition of her family. In her shop she sells various grocery items such as rice, maize, noodles, snacks, etc. With her shop income she fulfills the needs of her family.

Now Mrs. D. is requesting an Rs 30,000 loan to invest in her shop.

loans.use: To buy groceries for her shop

loans.name: Mrs. Shunri En Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The seventeE. people who make up this village bank loan live in Prek Doung village in Kandal province. Mrs. Shunri E. is the village bank president who was selected by all the members. Each of them will use the loan for different purposes.

Mrs. Shunri E. is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to sell for supporting her family. Aside from this she is also a government worker.  Through these activities, she supports two childrE. who attend the local school. She is a widow. She has a problem because whE. it was time for farming she didn't have enough money. Thus, Mrs. Shunri E. decided to seek a loan to start a late crop this year.

loans.use: To start a late crop this year

loans.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan is a 38-year-old married woman and the mother of three children. Her husband is a farmer and he also raises animals. Selling animals he has raised is his special source of income. Sharifan also operates an embroidered clothes business to supplement her husband’s income.

Sharifan would like to ask for a loan to buy animals (goats and sheep) for her husband’s business. Accomplishing this will allow him to increase his income and better provide for his family.

loans.use: To purchase animals for her husband's business

loans.name: Mujeres De Fe Y Esperanza 1,2 Group

texts.en:
Anal is the coordinator of her group, Mujeres de Fe y Esperanza (Women of Faith and Hope ), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients generally (many of whom recently emigrated to the Dominican Republic from Haiti).

Anal’s group is located in the areas surrounding Puerto Plata on the north coast of the Dominican Republic, an area famous for its natural beauty and its tourism industry, where (outside of the all-inclusive resorts) running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home there in a simple structure with her husband and two children.

Anal is excited to be taking her first loan with Esperanza and is excited to be having access to capital at low interest rates. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business running a butcher shop and selling "habichuela con dulce" a type of Dominican dessert.

Anal will use the profits to help support her children in the university. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To buy two pigs and a sack of beans

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more bags of cement to sell

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
Juvy K. is from the village of Gata Diot Clarin in Misamis Occidental. She is 40 years old. Juvy is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Juvy owns & operates a business in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals like "utan mongo" and utan langka." Juvy has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Juvy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Juvy is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Juvy from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food for sale

loans.name: Emelder

texts.en:
Emelder P. is currently in the business of selling both dried fish and fresh ones at the market and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell.  Emelder is 44 years old and is married to a businessman. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal from home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Susan is 45 years old and married to a policeman. She has 4 children and they all attend school. With the extra profits from her loan, Susan hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Louie

texts.en:
Louie S. is a 22-year-old married woman who supports her family by selling ice candy and other frozen food products. She lives in Brgy Lower Natimao-an, Carmen Cebu City, with her husband and their three-year-old child.
Louie has been a member of Kiva partner, NWTF-Project Dungganon, since 2007. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and her own efforts. By working hard in her ice candy and frozen food business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 4,000 PHP.
Louie is now borrowing 11,500 PHP as additional working capital for her business. This will be her fifth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 9,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Louie aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the 'Dungganon' way.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means 'honorable'). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them 'Dungganon' – a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of the community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Sarin Sa Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan has eighteen people who live in Trapeang Angk village in Takeo province. Mrs. Sarin S. is a village bank president who was born in 1959, selected by the other members who will use portion of their loan for varied goals. She is widow with a child who is a seamstress in garment factory. Her position is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. They all do work a lot but they can earn less income. So to improve condition family living, Mrs. Sarin S. is seeking for a loan to buy piglets, pig food, and cement to build pigsty to start new business.

loans.use: To buy piglets, pig food, and cement to build pigsty to start new business

loans.name: Nasuuti Womens Group-Mukono

texts.en: A. Janiffer, who leads this loan group, is 41 years old and went into business selling snacks six years ago. She works in Lweza-Mukono with the support of her husband, who strongly supported her decision to go into business. They are the proud parents to six lively and healthy children, all of whom attend school. She supplements her income by raising pigs. She works hard, but is kept going by a strong sense of purpose and determination. She now earns 50,000 Ugandan shillings a week, and plans to use this loan to buy more potatoes, cassava and pigs to sell. She also wants to expand her business by selling chickens as well.

loans.use: To expand several small businesses

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchasing sewing materials

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en: Cristina Y. is a married woman who lives in Purok Batad, Barangay Gairan, Bogo City, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: dried fish vending, a general store and a fishing business. Her husband, Eufenio Y., who is 42 years old, works as a checker and as a Barangay (village) Councilor to earn his living. They have four children who are from 10 to 20 years old. Cristina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon four years ago because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past nine loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 22,500 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 15,000, thus uplifting her family's standard of living. This time, for her 10th loan, Cristina is borrowing PHP 29,500 which she intends to use to purchase raw materials like dried fish so that she can continue to save for the future education of her children and to put up her own general store. Cristina is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Thim

texts.en:
Thim L., 36, is married and resides with her husband and four children in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Thirn grows rice and raises pigs for an income of USD 1 per day. Her husband is a truck driver, earning an income of USD 5 per day. The family has to spend USD 50 on food, USD 1 on electricity supply, USD 20 on the childrens education, and USD 5 on transportation every month.  

Thirn L. is requesting a loan of USD 400 to make repayments to her father. She is repaying the loan from her father to buy pigs and build the pig pen. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy pigs to raise and build pig pen

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en:
Ganhuyag S. is 34 years old and lives with his wife and two daughters in their own ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in the Huvsgul Province of Mongolia. Both of daughters, ages 12 and 16, attend local school, while Ganhuyag operates a transportation business in his town that he began in 2009 and has built into a stable operation. In addition, he purchases meats at wholesale prices which he resells at the Murun sub province for a profit.

A very active and business-minded man, in order to increase his earnings Ganhuyag plans to buy a bigger van that can carry more people. He is therefore requesting a 3,500,000 MNT loan for the purchase.

loans.use: To buy a new van

loans.name: Alan Javier

texts.es: Alan Javier Z. L. tiene 24 años de edad, es casado, padre de dos hijos y reside en el Barrio Flores en el municipio de La Unión, Olancho. Alan tiene un taller de mecánica que opera hace algunos años en una parte del solar de su casa de habitación y mientras él trabaja su esposa se dedica a cuidar a los niños y a los quehaceres del hogar. Alan aprendió su oficio como empleado de un taller y cuando él sintió que tenía el conocimiento necesario para trabajar solo decidió instalar su propio negocio. Su ventaja es que es una persona muy amigable así que su taller es muy visitado por vecinos de la comunidad. Una de sus dificultades es que no tiene otra entrada de dinero y en ciertas temporadas los trabajos a realizar son muy pocos. Él solicita el financiamiento para comprar más herramientas de trabajo y así prestar un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Su sueño es ampliar su negocio ofreciendo a sus clientes una variada gama de repuestos para vehículos y con esto tendrá más ingresos para darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.  Tiene varios ciclos en FAMA y es una persona muy responsable en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Alan Javier Z. L., 24, is married and the father of two children.  He lives in La Unión’s Flores neighborhood, Olancho.  He has had a machine shop in his house for several years and while he works his wife cares for the children and does the household chores.

Alan learned his skill as an employee in a workshop and when he felt he’d acquired sufficient skills to work independently he decided to set up his own workshop.
