In the future, Junjie would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds, vitamins, and other supplies to raise her livestock

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is married with four children, two of them in primary school. She started her shop business two years ago after selling her tobacco harvest. She started the shop so as to compliment/support her husband’s income. The shop is doing well and with the loan of US$150 from PEMCI she intends to build up her stock and improve profitability. She intends to quit the tobacco growing business due to its health hazards.

loans.use: Stock Shop

loans.name: Ruslan

texts.en: Ruslan was born in Salyan region, Yenikand village, and he is single. For the past two years, Ruslan has operated his own bridal-dress shop. He is known for his good taste and excellent stock of modern bridal dresses. He is requesting a loan of $700 which will enable him to expand the space in his shop.

loans.use: To expand the area of his shop

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela lives in her own house in the llojeta neighborhood of La Paz with her husband, Gumersindo Quenta, and her son. For 20 years her husband was employed at the mayor's office , but he recently decided to leave so that he could enjoy himself more, and spend time with Angela and their family. Because of this, he is now self-employed, and works to build furniture, walls, and improve the electrical connections of houses in his neighborhood.

Angela has opened a small store in their house where she started by selling sodas a household groceries. With the first loan that she took out from IMPRO, she stocked her store with a variety of products. This loan has been paid off in full. The current loan she is applying for will be used to purchase more goods for her store, so that she can meet the demand of her neighborhood clients who do not have access to the center of the city.

Angela's successful credit history with IMPRO qualifies her as a preferential client, and she is now able to apply for a loan of $100.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer

Ángela vive en casa propia en la zona de llojeta de la Ciudad de la Paz con su esposo, el señor Gumersindo Quenta y su hijo. El señor Gumersindo Quenta fue empleado de la alcaldía municipal hace más de 20 años pero por la edad no pudo jubilarse, por tal razón para mantener a su familia trabaja en la elaboración de muebles, construcción de muros, albañilería, conexiones eléctricas, etc.

Angela ha instalado una pequeña tienda donde al principio vendía solo refrescos; con el primer préstamo que saco de Impro fue llenando su tiendita a la fecha ya tiene una variedad de productos; dicho crédito ha sido pagado en su totalidad. El nuevo crédito que Angela solicita ahora es para comprar más productos para la tienda y poder atender las necesidades de la gente de su barrio y los alrededores, que no tienen acceso al centro de la ciudad.

Su antecedente histórico con Impro, la califica como cliente preferencial y puede acceder un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise to stock her store

loans.name: Isoken

texts.en: Mrs. Isoken E. is 48 years old and is happily married with 8 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State in Nigeria. She has been with LAPO for two years. She sells ladies' wear and needs this loan to buy more clothes, shoes and bags to sell.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in different types of animals

loans.name: Abiola

texts.en: Mrs. Abiola A. is 38 years old, married, with 4 children. She lives in Mushin, Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells kerosene to people, and has been a member of LAPO for the past 4 years. She has been in her business since 1996 and needs a loan of $400 to buy more kerosene for sale.

loans.use: To buy more kerosene for sale

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Sareth, 41, and her husband, Kuch Von, have been married since 1990. Their four children, ages 6-17, are all attending local schools. Sareth and her husband have had a business of buying and reselling flowers and bananas for the past 27 years. Once a week, they drive 10 km to purchase their goods from local farmers before making the journey into Phnom Penh to resell at the large markets there. They currently sell seven varieties of flowers and two of banana. Von also farms tobacco and raises pigs to help support the family.

Sareth is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1,200. She will use this loan to purchase a one-season contract at specific flower and banana farms. Previous loans were used for the same purpose. By this system, the wholesaler estimates the output per farm and bids on a contract for everything grown that season. Because of the high up-front cost, Sareth finds it difficult to save this money, which is why she is seeking another loan. These contracts for goods will provide the family with a stable income over the next many months.

loans.use: Buy flowers and bananas for reselling

loans.name: Ruziboy

texts.en: Ruziboy M. lives in Nausky region, Tajikistan. He is married and has 5 children. He decided to become the client of MicroInvest in 2004 because he heard so many successful stories from his friends who were helped by MicroInvest loans.  The business stability and income increase helped him to return his previous loans. Mr.Malloboev is engaged in the home business of the livestock raising. He is also typesetter but he continues to work in the livestock business started by his father.  He is requesting a loan to purchase a bull.

loans.use: For the purchase of a bull

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 45 years old and is married with 5 children, age 28, 24, 13, 9 and 5. She and her husband also take care of one other child, age 5. Amina owns a small cafe, which she started in 2007. She works every day from 8 am to 6 pm at her business.

In the past, Amina has taken out and successfully repaid loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Sanavbar

texts.en:
R. Sanavbar lives in the J.Rasulov region of Tajikistan. She is not married but she has a child. Despite the fact that she is a single mother, she is full of enthusiasm and ready to work hard to ensure a happy future for her child.

Mrs. Sanavbar sells men's clothing. She has 10 years of experience in the business and she dreams of having a large-scale business. She has a good assortment of clothing.

Mrs. Sanavbar has applied to KIVA for a business development loan of 1800 STJ for 8 months to import new seasonal goods.

loans.use: To import new seasonal clothing

loans.name: Vidalina

texts.es:
VIDALINA is an enterprising woman who is grows flowers inside her home, cares much for their growth and development, and, when these beautiful flowers sprout, sells them at fairs and to her friends. She is also involved in animal husbandry. Now that her son has decided to study in another city, her ability to work and her hopes for improvement have increased. For this reason, she is seeking a loan in order to acquire more seeds and animals to increase her income and contribute to the wishes of her beloved son.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva volunteer.

VIDALINA, es un a mujer emprendedora que se dedica al cultivo de flores dentro de su hogar, cuida mucho su crecimiento y desarrollo para cuando estas broten le otorguen bellas flores a fin de venderlas en las ferias y a sus amistades. También se dedica a la crianza de animales. Ahora que su hijo a decidido estudiar en otra ciudad de su país su capacidad de trabajo y deseos de mejora se han maximizado por esa razón solicita un préstamo a fin de adquirir mayor cantidad de semillas y animalitos a fin de incrementar sus ingresos y colaborar con los deseos de su amado hijo.

loans.use: To acquire more seeds for flower cultivation and more animals for her animal husbandry business.

loans.name: Bartolomé

texts.es:
In the “Five Pines” district of Chinandega town, Bartolomé P. has spent the last six years establishing a hardware store which he runs from his house, offering all types of materials to his customers in the area. It is necessary to state that being a single father of three children his efforts are greater in order that he may be able to provide them with all the necessary condition of life for their development.

Ceprodel have been a cornerstone of his business, for the simple reason that he has benefited from credits which have been of enormous use in the marketing of his hardware products. Each and every one of his loans has been repaid on time and in the manner agreed by both parties.

Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer

En el municipio de Cinco Pinos en la ciudad de Chinandega el señor Bartolomé P. se ha dedicado desde hace seis años al negocio de ferretería el cual atiende en su casa de habitación ofreciendo todo tipo de materiales a sus clientes en el sector. Es necesario destacar que por ser un caballero padre de tres hijos sus esfuerzos son mayores por lograr proporcionarles todas las condiciones de vida necesarias para su desarrollo.

Ceprodel ha sido un pilar en el negocio por la sencilla razón que le ha beneficiado con créditos que le has sido de muchísimo beneficio para la comercialización de sus productos ferreteros. Hoy en día él acude una vez mas a Ceprodel para obtener el crédito que le permita la compra de los productos ferreteros para comercializarlos. Todos y cada uno de los créditos que el ha tenido han sido pagados en tiempo y forma de acuerdo a lo establecido por ambas partes.

loans.use: Purchase of tools and materials

loans.name: Millicent's Group

texts.en:
Agyenkwa Group is a group of eleven women whose name means savior. For some time now they have traded in various items, ranging from tubers and cereals to legumes and vegetables to used clothing. All these women have children; the leader has eight. She prepares and sells fufu (pounded cassava eating with soup) rice balls, banku (milled and boiled maize), and other food items.

They are hard working but due to large family sizes they spend their working capital supporting their children. They endure economic hardship and therefore came together to form the group. Members want to use the loan to buy produce and cloths to increase their income so that they can better support their families. They co-guarantee for each other to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more fresh tubers of yams, cassava, rice, used clothing, vegetables, and other items for resale.

loans.name: Phalla

texts.en:
Mrs. Phalla K. is 28-years-old and the mother of three children, one of whom is attending school. The other children are too young to work or study. Mrs. Phalla K. and her husband Mr. Loeurng Sam are farmers. The soil on their plantation field is infertile, so Mrs. Phalla K. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers so that she can grow rice. In the past, Mrs. Phalla K. obtained a loan to buy piglets for breeding. She has paid off this loan.

Last year, one of Mrs. Phalla K.’s children got dengue fever. She had to spend $500 to cure her child, which is part of the reason she does not have enough money to buy fertilizers for the field. Her husband is on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers so that she can grow rice.

loans.name: Maria Ynes Del Carme

texts.es:
Maria Ynes is a single mother, and owing to the necessity she had of raising children, she decided to dedicate herself to selling clothes, seeing that this was not reaching her needs, she started to also sell toys and groceries. This is how, little by little, her sales have been increased and now she wishes to have a larger inventory to offer her customers more options.

She needs a loan of $250, which she will repay in three months, to buy merchandise and offer her customers more options.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

María Ynes es madre soltera y debido a la necesidad que tenia para mantener a hijos decidió dedicarse a la venta de ropa, viendo que con esto no le alcanzaba empezó a vender además juguetes y bisutería, es así como poco a poco sus ventas han ido aumentando y ahora desea tener mas inventario para ofrecerles mas opciones a sus clientes. Ella necesita un préstamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar mercancía y ofrecerle más opciones a sus clientes.

loans.use: Buying merchandise

loans.name: Ndella

texts.fr: Ndella S. est née le 26 janvier 1978 à Rufisque.Elle habite au quartier DVF dans la commune de Bambey avec son mari. Elle fait de la couture depuis trois ans.
texts.en:
Ndella S. was born on January 26, 1978 in Rufisque. She lives with her husband in the DVF quarter in the city of Bambey. She's been a seamstress for three years.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sewing

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George K. is the father of one child who is currently in school.  He belongs to the community group named King David Trust Group. In this group, members agree to guarantee each other as social collateral to order to access loans. 

George is a 32 year old businessman. He is a supplier and distributor of cement in his community. He has been in this business for the past year. There is a constant demand for cement since it is necessary for building.  He is requesting a loan to buy a truck so he can deliver large quantities of cement to his customers.  He also needs the loan to re-stock his shop and improve sales.  The loan will allow him to grow his business.

loans.use: To buy increased stock of cement.

loans.name: Maria Celene

texts.es:
Maria es socia de Banco Comunal El Pino. Maria es conviviente, tiene 37 años y 3 hijos de 17, 7 y 3 años. Todos estan en la escuela.       
Maria tiene su negocio de venta de salchipapas,ella vende desde hace 2 años tiene un carrito sanguchero,  atiende todos los días por las noches , su negocio está ubicado en una zona comercial.
Maria necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, dinero que será invertido en la compra de insumos para su negocio (paltos descartables , bolsas)todo al por mayor.
María desde que recibe los prestamos ha producido un poco mas. Maria sueña con  comprar mas carritos sangucheros para trabajar en otras zonas.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the communal bank El Pino. Maria is 37 years old and lives with her partner. She has three children ages 17, 7 and 3. All are in school. Maria has a business selling potato and sausage kebabs which she has been selling for two years. She sells her kebabs from a cart which she runs every night in a commercial zone. Maria needs a loan in the amount of $400 which she will invest in purchasing supplies for her business (disposable plates, bags) all at wholesale. Since she has been receiving loans, Maria has been able to produce more. She dreams of buying more carts so that she can work in other areas.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Manzo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of supplies for her business such as disposable plates and bags.

loans.name: Parviz

texts.en:
Parviz Z. is 22 years old. He is a young hairdresser who works in the barber shop in a small village in the southern part of Azerbaijan. He started his business in 2006, after getting an education in this field. Parviz is married and lives with his parents, who are on pension now.  

Parviz works very hard because his income from this business is the sole financial source for his family. Parviz is very polite with his clients--that’s why his place is always full of people.  He starts his working day at 9 in the morning and finishes at 11 at night. Parviz rents a place and pays monthly rent, and he must finance all changes and improvements himself. 

Parviz would like to expand his business and purchase modern tools for hairdressing, so he applied for a loan of 1200 USD. Parviz is very excited to implement new tools in his business so he can attract more clients and increase his income. Parviz's wife is expecting a child, so Parviz is working even harder than usual to cover all the needs of the new baby. Parviz and his family appreciate your support very much!

loans.use: Purchase new tools for hairdressing

loans.name: Magadlaine Bashir Masih Gull Group

texts.en:
Magadlaine baji is 32 years old and married. She has been living in the city of Arifwala, Pakistan for the past 15 years. Her husband's name is B. M. G.; he works in a cotton factory. She is the mother of five children: four sons and one daughter. Her eldest son is in the decorative embroidery business. He collects orders from big markets and signs a commitment to complete the order in 15 days. His mother Magadlaine baji helps him complete the commitment. Her other kids are in kindergarten.

Magadlaine baji successfully repaid her previous two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy materials (beads, colored thread, and sketches) to expand her son’s decorative embroidery business.

Magadlaine baji is the leader of a group of several women. Hamidan baji wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables for her vegetable selling business. Rasheedan baji wants a loan to buy goats for her animal selling business. Nazia baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits for her fruit selling business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy materials for a decorative embroidery business

loans.name: Jiguiya (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Jiguiya de l’association Faso kanu  de  Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) est un   regroupement de cinq femmes qui vivent toutes dans des grandes familles traditionnelles à Dar Salam II. Elles sont toutes mariées et mères d’au moins quatre enfants.
Pour augmenter la taille de leurs activités, elles ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso    
Leur activité principale  est la vente de beignet et de viande, elles  vendent au carrefour le matin de bonne heure (beignet avec la tête de mouton bien cuite) un petit déjeuner très apprécié par les  habitants de la localité.
Le groupe Jiguiya de Faso kanu a connu Soro Yiriwaso  il y a plus d’un an, il  est à son troisième prêt après avoir remboursé correctement les deux premiers.
Le beignet est à base de petit mil ou du riz qu’elles achètent en gros avec les paysans à la foire du village à un prix abordable pour transformer et vendre.
 Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des sacs de riz de petit mil et des bidons d’huiles.
Le bénéfice estimé avec ce prêt est de 110 000 FCFA par cliente. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour payer les intérêts du prêt et s’occuper des dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
The group Jiguiya of the association Faso Kanu de Koutiala (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali) is composed of five women who all live in large traditional families in Dar Salam II. They are all married and mothers of at least four children. To expand their work, they have decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, which they discovered over a year ago. Their principal work involves the sale of beignets (a kind of doughnut) and meat. At the crossroads early in the morning, they sell beignets with well-done sheep’s head, which is a breakfast highly appreciated by the town’s inhabitants.

Beignets are made of millet or rice, which are purchased wholesale from peasants at the village fair at affordable prices. The current loan will be used to buy sacks of rice and millet and drums of cooking oil. The estimated profit is 110,000 francs CFA per member. This profit will be used to pay the loan interest and to take care of family expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, millet, and cooking oil

loans.name: Phea's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Phea M. is a group leader of five who all live in Tropeang Srongae village in Kampong Chhnang province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Vorn Vy, is a musician who has been hired by the people to perform at wedding ceremonies, parties, and others events. Mrs. Phea M. is applying to a loan so that she can buy pigs and start a new business. She is 27 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school. 

Three members in this group loans are end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. They are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK’s main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To buy pigs to start new pig breeding business to earn more income

loans.name: Makunguru Group

texts.en:
Veneranda has been a business woman in the Mwanjelwa neighborhood of Mbeya for 4 years. She currently earns an average monthly profit of $175. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.
  
She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more items for her business. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to expand her business.  


Venerand is 35 years old, married, and has three children. She will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Bupe, who also has her own small business in Mbeya.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es: El señor Leonor C. nació en Luque en el año 1937, vive con la Sra. Victoriana Ferreira Romero  desde hace mas de 30 años. Don Leonor tiene una despensa en su domicilio ubicado en el tercer barrio de Luque. Opera con la Fundación Paraguaya desde el año 1997. Ambas personas dirigen el negocio ya que no tienen hijos menores y los recursos financieros lo destinan normalmente para mejorar su local comercial y comprar artículos comestibles, a granel y mercerias varias a fin de aumentar su inventario y poder asi mejorar su ingreso familiar a traves del comercio al por menor.
texts.en:
Leonor C. was born in Luque in 1937; he has lived with Victoriana Ferreira Romero for more than 30 years. Leonor has a grocery store in his home located in the third neighborhood in Luque. He has been working with the Paraguaya Foundation since 1997. Both Leonor and Victoriana run the business given that they do not have young children. Their financial resources are usually destined for improvements to their commercial locale and for the purchase of food items in bulk and assorted merchandise, with aim of increasing their inventory to be able to improve the family’s income through retail commerce.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase vegetables, drinks, food items, and general merchandise.

loans.name: Efrain

texts.es: El señor Efraín tiene 40 años de edad, habita en el barrio Memorial Sandino en la ciudad de Managua, casado y con una hija de 18 años que trabaja como secretaria en un centro de comida rápida. El se desempeña como oficial de la policía Nacional,  tiene veintiún años de trabajar sirviendo a la comunidad, este es su noveno ciclo en Afodenic, que se ha beneficiado para hacer las mejoras  a su casa. Con esta solicitud va a seguir mejorando su casa va a construir el porche para mejor comodidad lo cual da las gracias a la institución por hacer sus metas realidad lo cual espera en un futuro poder seguir trabajando.
texts.en:
40-year old Señor Efraín lives in the neighbourhood of Memorial Sandino in the city of Managua. He is married and has an 18-year old daughter who is employed as a secretary in a fast food centre. He earns his living as an officer in the national police force where he has worked for twenty-one years serving the community. This is his ninth loan with Kiva partner Afodenic, and he has benefited greatly by being able to make improvements to his house. He plans to use this loan to continue with the renovations, by building a porch which will make his home more comfortable. Efraín wishes to thank the organisation that enables him to make his goals reality. He expects to continue working well into the future.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy materials to build a porch

loans.name: Felipa

texts.es:
Felipa es socia del Banco Comunal Maria Celeste.
Felipa es soltera, tiene 56 años y 1 hijo, Felipa tiene un taller de confección de prendas de vestir en su casa, confecciona edredones, sabanas que vende en los mercados también vende ropa a pedido, sus ventas son al crédito.
Felipa necesita un préstamo de 2500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de telas.
Los sueños de Felipa son ampliar su taller con mas maquinas.
texts.en:
Felipa is a member of the Maria Celeste community bank. Felipa, 56, is married and has a son. Felipa has a sewing shop in her house. She makes quilts and sheets that she sells in the markets. She also makes clothes to order. Her sales are on credit. Felipa needs a loan for 2,500 PEN to buy fabric. Felipa’s dream is to expand her shop with more machines.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fabric

loans.name: Comité Divino Niño Jesús Group

texts.es:
El Comité de Mujeres de nombre Divino Niño Jesús, se conformó en fecha 05 de noviembre del 2008., gracias a que la actual Directora General, la Sra. Castorina A., quien se dedica a la elaboración y venta de comidas, contactó con la asesora en una reunión semanal que la misma tenía en la zona, para enterarse de la forma de trabajo que tiene el Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. Una vez asesorada acerca del Programa logró juntar a 18 mujeres quienes se encuentran trabajando muy a gusto ya en el 2° ciclo, en forma conjunta y solidaria dentro del programa.
El grupo en el transcurso del 1° ciclo, pasó por varios inconvenientes, ya que la Directora de Finanzas en aquel entonces sufrió un grave accidente en donde perdió la vida, pero el grupo gracias a su trabajo solidario logro salir adelante y seguir trabajando con el programa.
El promedio de crédito retirado por cada integrante es de 430.000 Gs., lo cual va destinado para diferentes actividades tales como: venta de comidas, venta de mercerías, venta de mercaderías para la despensa (arroz, azúcar, fideos, lácteos, panificados, yerba, etc.), venta de ropas, venta de lencerías, venta de remedios naturales, venta de perfumes, venta de cosméticos, venta de frutas y verduras, venta de carbón, etc.
Todas ellas realizan actividades para recaudar fondos, se ayudan mutuamente para llegar a los objetivos en común que todas tienen dentro del grupo y con la Fundación Paraguaya.
Participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y tienen un trabajo solidario impecable.
texts.en:
The Divine Baby Jesus Women's Committee was formed on 5 November 2008 thanks to the efforts of the current general director, Mrs. Castorina A., who is involved in the elaboration and sale of prepared meals. She made contact with the advisor during a weekly meeting taking place in the area to gather information regarding the work of the Committee of Entrepreneur Women. Once she was informed about the program, she managed to gather together 18 women who are now happily working together in a second cycle. The group suffered major obstacles during the first cycle because the financial director at that time was victim of a serious accident that cost her her life. However, the group stuck together and was able to continue working with the program. Each participant withdraws on average 430,000 guaraní which are used for various activities such as: sale of prepared meals, sale of notions, sale of basic foodstuffs (rice, sugar, pasta, dairy products, bakery good, herbs, etc.) sale of clothing and lingerie, sale of natural remedies, sale of perfume and cosmetics, fruits and vegetables, charcoal, etc. All of the members take part in fund-raising activities and help each other to reach the common objectives which they have within the group and with the Paraguaya Foundation. They actively participate in the weekly meetings and have impeccable cooperative work skills.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for the general store (rice, sugar, herbs, dairy products, bakery goods, soft drinks,etc.), to purchase ingredients for preparing meals, to purchase clothing and sewing supplies, to purchase lingerie and natural home remedy ingredients, to purchase fruits and vegetables, meats, pefumes,cosmetics, charcoal, manicure and pedicure supplies, etc.
